item.title: Una teoría sobre el origen de la covid separó a este matrimonio de científicos
item.description: En 2020, una viróloga china huyó a EE. UU., ayudada por aliados del presidente Trump que pretendían promover sus teorías no demostradas sobre los orígenes de la COVID-19. Su esposo sigue sin poder encontrarla.
item.dc:creator: Katie J.M. Baker

media:content.media:credit: Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Li-Meng Yan habló en 2021 en una cumbre celebrada en Anchorage, Alaska, sobre el tratamiento temprano ambulatorio de la COVID-19.

item.title: Word of the Day: fruition
item.description: This word has appeared in 444 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: In Thailand and Cambodia, Taking Shelter (Again) as Fighting Reignites
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people fled a deadly border conflict, the authorities said, some sheltering at a racetrack in Thailand and some near temples in Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:credit: Wason Wanichakorn/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A Thai resident who fled clashes between Thai and Cambodian soldiers, using a cellphone while taking shelter in Buriram Province, Thailand, on Tuesday.

item.title: Jeremy O. Harris Is Released From Custody in Japan
item.description: The Tony-nominated playwright was arrested last month on suspicion of attempted drug smuggling. He was released on Monday, Japanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Kiuko Notoya

media:content.media:credit: Robby Klein/Getty Images for IMDb
media:content.media:description: The Tony-nominated playwright and actor Jeremy O. Harris earlier this year.

item.title: Between Pakistan and Afghanistan, a Trade War With No End in Sight
item.description: The Pakistani and Afghan governments have locked their populations in a trade war threatening the livelihoods of millions.

media:content.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: People selling food in front of Lala Jee Sweets & Bakers, a famous bakery in Peshawar’s Board Bazar, last month.

item.title: With Cheap Tickets and Lax Etiquette, a Theater Builds an Older Fan Base
item.description: The Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul is popular in a country where 70-year-olds now outnumber people in their 20s.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Woohae Cho

media:content.media:description: The ticket booth at the Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul, the capital of South Korea, in November.

item.title: A pesar de la guerra y el alto al fuego, Hamás sigue controlando partes de Gaza
item.description: Un alto al fuego tras dos años de guerra con Israel ha permitido que Hamás vuelva a reforzar su control del poder. “Sigue en pie”, dijo un funcionario israelí.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Combatientes de Hamás cerca de Jan Yunis, Gaza, en febrero, durante la entrega de los cadáveres de rehenes israelíes como parte de un acuerdo de intercambio.

item.title: Between Pakistan and Afghanistan, a Trade War With No End in Sight
item.description: After deadly cross-border military clashes, the Pakistani and Afghan governments have locked their populations in a trade war threatening the livelihoods of millions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Zia ur-Rehman

media:content.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 9, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 9, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Blessings for Children Clad in Kimonos, and Fur
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 9, 2025.

item.title: La fiscalía de Honduras emite orden de captura a Juan Orlando Hernández
item.description: El exmandatario hondureño fue indultado por el presidente Donald Trump y liberado de prisión en EE. UU. Ahora lo buscan las autoridades de su país.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Foto de consorcio por Andy Buchanan
media:content.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández fue presidente de Honduras de 2014 a 2022.

item.title: Massachusetts Church Keeps Anti-ICE Nativity Scene, Defying Diocese Leaders
item.description: The Christmas display, which replaces Jesus, Mary and Joseph with a sign saying “ICE Was Here,” has drawn criticism from Catholic leaders and immigration officials.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell

media:content.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A Nativity scene at St. Susanna Parish in Dedham, Mass., displays a sign reading “ICE Was Here” in the spot where Jesus, Mary and Joseph would normally be.

item.title: Honduras Issues Warrant for Juan Orlando Hernández
item.description: The attorney general said he had asked Interpol to detain Juan Orlando Hernández, who was freed from a U.S. prison last week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Andy Buchanan
media:content.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández was president of Honduras from 2014 to 2022 and was convicted on drug-trafficking charges in the United States last year.

item.title: Top N.Y. Cannabis Official Resigns as Major Investigation Is Dropped
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul demanded the resignation of the head of New York’s Office of Cannabis Management following the withdrawal of a case against a Long Island-based company.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Omnium headquarters in Hauppauge, N.Y., earlier this year. It is unclear why a case against the company was withdrawn.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 9, 2025
item.description: Kate Hawkins remains undecided.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: ‘Marjorie Prime’ Review: A.I. Gave Her Back Her Husband. Was It Worth It?
item.description: June Squibb stars in the Broadway premiere of Jordan Harrison’s meditation on grief and the nature of human and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

media:content.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: June Squibb, right, plays the titular character of “Marjorie Prime,” with Christopher Lowell as an A.I. replica of her deceased husband as he was in his 30s.

item.title: Agua o aranceles: Trump vuelve a amenazar a México
item.description: El presidente Trump vuelve a la carga contra uno de los mayores socios comerciales de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Presa de Las Vírgenes, en el estado mexicano de Chihuahua, fronterizo con Texas y Nuevo México.

item.title: DeSantis Designates CAIR, Muslim Advocacy Group, a ‘Terrorist Organization’
item.description: The executive order from the Florida governor came after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration last month.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s order comes after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration against the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

item.title: Trump Again Threatens Tariffs on Mexico Over Long-Running Water Dispute
item.description: The threat is the latest aggressive action that President Trump has taken against America’s biggest trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Las Vírgenes dam in the Mexican state of Chihuahua, which borders Texas and New Mexico.

item.title: El Congreso presiona al Pentágono para que revele toda la información sobre los ataques a embarcaciones
item.description: Demócratas y republicanos han solicitado, sin éxito, que se liberen los videos completos del embate del 2 de septiembre. Ahora usarán una iniciativa de ley para obtener respuesta del gobierno de Trump.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth, ha publicado en las redes sociales imágenes editadas de los ataques, pero hasta ahora se ha negado a compartir el video completo con los legisladores.

item.title: Trump Insists Tariffs Will Buoy the Economy and Ease Cost Concerns
item.description: The president rolled out a $12 billion bailout for farmers as he makes the case that his policy is working — or will soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The president announced $12 billion in bailout money for America’s farmers who have been battered in large part by his trade policies.

item.title: Trump Offers Farmers $12 Billion Bailout From Trade War
item.description: President Trump promised struggling farmers billions in federal aid during a round-table meeting on Monday. This comes after China boycotted American farm products in retaliation for U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The money for farmers will come mostly from the Agriculture Department’s Farmer Bridge Assistance program.

item.title: Globos de Oro 2026: la lista completa de nominaciones
item.description: Estas son las películas y series que optan a la edición 83 de los Globos de Oro. La ceremonia se transmitirá el 11 de enero.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: Supreme Court Questions N.Y. Ban on Religious Exemptions for Vaccines
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court directed a lower court to review the ban, which applies to strict vaccine requirements in New York schools.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Up to 20 percent of students had religious exemptions from vaccines at some schools in Rockland County, N.Y., where there was a measles outbreak in 2019.

item.title: Federal Judge Finds Trump’s Halt on Wind Energy Is Illegal
item.description: The president ordered a stop to permits for all wind farms on federal lands and waters. A judge called that “capricious.”
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer

media:content.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vineyard Wind Farm, about 15 miles south of the coast of Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts.

item.title: Justices Seem Poised to Expand Trump’s Powers
item.description: Also, Paramount made a hostile bid for Warner Bros. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times

item.title: Democrats’ Proposal Would Halt D.H.S. Courthouse Arrests of Migrants
item.description: About 80 percent of immigrants have skipped appointments to avoid detention, risking their path to legal status, a New York congressman said.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley

media:content.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A team of federal agents arrest a man leaving immigration court at the Ted Weiss Federal Building in Manhattan in July.

item.title: John Noble Wilford, Times Reporter Who Covered the Moon Landing, Dies at 92
item.description: He gave readers a comprehensive and lyrical account of the historic mission in 1969. His science coverage as a Pulitzer-winning journalist and an author took him around the world.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: John Noble Wilford in 1981. Recalling his coverage of the moon landing, he said, “I thought to myself, yes, this is the biggest story I will probably ever write in my career.”

item.title: Bruce Blakeman Moves to Run for Governor of New York
item.description: Mr. Blakeman, the Nassau County executive, would face a bitter Republican primary showdown with Representative Elise Stefanik.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Bruce Blakeman, 70, is a political force on Long Island and an ally of President Trump.

item.title: One Hundred Schoolchildren Released After Abduction in Nigeria
item.description: One hundred children who had been kidnapped from a Catholic school in northwestern Nigeria last month were released on Sunday. This is part of a larger trend of kidnappings in Nigeria, where victims are released in exchange for ransom.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Ifeanyi Immanuel Bakwenye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A classroom at St. Mary’s Catholic boarding school in Niger State, Nigeria, last month following the kidnapping.

item.title: Why Democratic Governors Argue They Are the Party’s Best Shot for 2028
item.description: A long list of people could test that theory, though governors have struggled to make the leap to presidential nominations in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan.

item.title: Trump Clears Sale of More Powerful Nvidia A.I. Chips to China
item.description: Approval for the H200 chip followed months of haggling between tech industry backers and defense hawks.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration wants to encourage Chinese companies to use Nvidia’s H200 chip while limiting sales of the company’s newest chips, known as Blackwell.

item.title: Spicy Peanut and Pumpkin Soup
item.description: This recipe is a promise of warmth on those cool autumn nights. Habanero chiles and peanuts both feature heavily in Nigerian cuisine, and this soup is an adaptation of a long-simmered stew common to much of West Africa.

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel’s ABC Deal Is Extended Through May 2027
item.description: “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” became a flashpoint about free speech in the country after it was temporarily suspended this year.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin

media:content.media:credit: Randy Holmes/Disney, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Jimmy Kimmel’s show was briefly suspended by ABC in September because of comments he made about the man accused of killing Charlie Kirk.

item.title: N.Y. Archdiocese Will Negotiate Sex-Abuse Settlement for 1,300 Accusers
item.description: The archdiocese will raise at least $300 million to fund the settlement. It has agreed with its accusers on a mediator to conduct negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The New York Archdiocese said it had sold its Manhattan headquarters to raise money for a sex-abuse settlement.

item.title: Russian Court Sentences 4 Soldiers to Prison for Killing Texan
item.description: Russell Bonner Bentley III, 64, who was living in the occupied Donbas region of Ukraine, was beaten and tortured to death after he was suspected of being an American saboteur, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman
media:content.media:description: Russell Bonner Bentley III visiting a memorial to victims of Nazi killings, in Donetsk, Ukraine, in 2017.

item.title: Donald E. Petersen, 97, Who Rescued Ford Motor Co., Is Dead
item.description: An ex-Marine and a 40-year company veteran, he turned a nearly bankrupt money loser into the world’s most profitable automaker.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

media:content.media:credit: Jim Russell/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Donald E. Petersen, foreground, in 1981 touring a Philco-Ford of Canada factory with the plant manager, Bill Quindlin. Mr. Petersen, who spent 40 years with Ford, helped develop the Mustang, Thunderbird, LTD, Maverick and Continental Mark III.

item.title: A Frustrated Congress Pushes the Pentagon to Produce Its Boat Strike Orders
item.description: In a sign of bipartisan frustration with the Defense Department, the final defense policy bill aims to compel the Pentagon to share execute orders and video documentation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has posted edited footage of the strikes on social media, but has so far refused to share the full video with lawmakers.

item.title: Terry Rozier of Miami Heat Pleads Not Guilty in Gambling Case
item.description: The N.B.A. player has been charged in federal court with money laundering conspiracy and wire fraud conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Terry Rozier, who is in his 11th season, has been placed on leave from the N.B.A.

item.title: America Must Prepare for the Future of War
item.description: The nature of war has drastically changed. The editorial board argues that the U.S. must reform its military.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board and James Robinson

item.title: G.O.P. Senators Push Health Care Options as Vote Looms
item.description: The Senate is set to vote later this week on a three-year extension of Affordable Care Act subsidies that Republicans oppose. The G.O.P. has yet to coalesce around an alternative.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Bernie Moreno, along with Senator Susan Collins, has proposed a measure to extend Affordable Care Act tax breaks for two years.

item.title: Trump Backtracks on Releasing Video of Boat Strike
item.description: The president said he would defer to his defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, on whether to release a video showing a follow-up attack that killed survivors of a Sept. 2 strike on an alleged drug smuggling boat.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said last week that “we’d certainly release, no problem,” speaking of a video of a U.S. military strike that killed two people hanging on to the remnants of a suspected drug-smuggling boat.

item.title: Trump’s Birthday Becomes Free National Park Day as MLK Day and Juneteenth Are Cut
item.description: Visitors will instead get free entry on President Trump’s birthday, which coincides with Flag Day.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People

media:content.media:credit: Josh Edelson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Grinnell Lake at Glacier National Park in Montana. The National Park Service will offer free entrance to U.S. citizens and permanent residents on 10 days next year, up from six free days this year.

item.title: The Second ‘China Shock’
item.description: Chinese exports are flooding the developing world, and the social consequences are bound to be profound.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Geely manufacturing plant in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Clerk in Murdaugh Trial Is Sentenced to Probation for Perjury and Other Charges
item.description: Becky Hill helped manage the 2023 trial in which Alex Murdaugh was convicted of murdering his wife and younger son.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Jeffrey Collins/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Becky Hill, the former clerk of courts in Colleton County, S.C., in court on Monday. She had been accused of perjury, misuse of public funds and sharing court information under court seal with a reporter.

item.title: Youth Mental Health Improved When Schools Reopened, Study Finds
item.description: With the end of school shutdowns, children’s mental health appointments fell sharply, though other factors may have contributed.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

media:content.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nine months after schools reopened, the probability that a child would be treated for a mental health condition was reduced by 43 percent, from 2.8 percent during the shutdown period, a study published Monday found.

item.title: Pups in Kimonos Receive Blessings During Japanese Holiday
item.description: Pet owners dressed their dogs in kimonos and custom belts to receive blessings at a Shinto shrine last month. This was part of a children’s festival, Shichi-Go-San, or 7-5-3, which has recently been revamped to include pets as well.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:description: Hiroko, Kana and Risa Matsuki holding their Chihuahua-dachshund mix dogs — Happy, 5, and Oreo, 3 — as the shrine’s chief priest, Kenji Kaji, chants a blessing.

item.title: These Tips Make Latkes Easier to Fry and More Flavorful
item.description: Turns out, pickles are a secret ingredient.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Gelen

media:content.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne. Prop Stylist: Megan Hedgpeth.
media:content.media:description: Developing a crackling crust for latkes is simple once you understand the basics of frying.
